title: The Samsung Galaxy S25
description: The Samsung Galaxy S25. The S25 Edge is definitely Samsung’s most interesting phone this year, and the Ultra is probably the best one, but honestly the whole lineup is a little boring this time? Still, I really do appreciate that Samsung’s shipping a high-end, reasonably sized, full-featured flagship smartphone for $800.
issueTitle: The 2025 Android upgrade cycle has begun

title: S25 Edge
description: The Samsung Galaxy S25. The S25 Edge is definitely Samsung’s most interesting phone this year, and the Ultra is probably the best one, but honestly the whole lineup is a little boring this time? Still, I really do appreciate that Samsung’s shipping a high-end, reasonably sized, full-featured flagship smartphone for $800.

title: Severance: dive deep into the Apple TV Plus workplace thriller
description: More in: Severance: dive deep into the Apple TV Plus workplace thriller
issueTitle: New year, new Switch, new Severance

title: check out our annual awards
description: I also have for you a big report from CES in Las Vegas. This edition of Installer is a little different than most, just because we saw so many new things, and so many new things launched, and in many cases, it’s hard to know whether any of it will ever hit shelves. So think of this as part Installer, part CES recap, part “David hopes desperately these things actually ship” list. But I tried hard to pick out the stuff I’m confident will actually end up on sale at some point soon and might be wort
issueTitle: The best actually real stuff at CES 2025

title: Meta’s
issueTitle: The AR and VR headsets you’ll actually wear

title: SocialAI
description: SocialAI. The reaction to this “social network” for iOS, where you post and a thousand AI bots immediately reply, was so funny. Some people loved it, some hated it, half seemed to think it was a joke.
issueTitle: A social network where everyone’s a bot

title: Notion
issueTitle: Two new must-have Android apps

title: The Light Phone 3
description: The Light Phone 3. The new version of one of the best minimalist phones comes with a better screen, a camera, an NFC chip, and some big ambitions about replacing your phone. I don’t think I’m physically capable of ditching my smartphone, but I want this thing so badly.
issueTitle: The super simple gadget trying to replace your phone

title: some big ambitions
description: The Light Phone 3. The new version of one of the best minimalist phones comes with a better screen, a camera, an NFC chip, and some big ambitions about replacing your phone. I don’t think I’m physically capable of ditching my smartphone, but I want this thing so badly.
issueTitle: The super simple gadget trying to replace your phone

title: Apple Passwords
description: Apple Passwords. We’ll talk a lot more about all of Apple’s WWDC announcements as they start to roll out, but this one’s worth thinking about now: Apple’s cross-platform, presumably well-integrated passwords app looks really good.
issueTitle: The super simple gadget trying to replace your phone

title: all of Apple’s WWDC announcements
description: Apple Passwords. We’ll talk a lot more about all of Apple’s WWDC announcements as they start to roll out, but this one’s worth thinking about now: Apple’s cross-platform, presumably well-integrated passwords app looks really good.
issueTitle: The super simple gadget trying to replace your phone

title: Introducing Kino Pro Video Camera
description: Kino. The team at Lux doesn’t really miss. They made Halide for photos, the nifty Orion iPad monitor tool, and now Kino, a video app that is somehow both really simple and absurdly powerful. I love a good noir filter. (I got a lot of recommendations for this one this week — thanks to everyone who sent them in!)
issueTitle: A better way to take video on your phone

title: Halide
description: Kino. The team at Lux doesn’t really miss. They made Halide for photos, the nifty Orion iPad monitor tool, and now Kino, a video app that is somehow both really simple and absurdly powerful. I love a good noir filter. (I got a lot of recommendations for this one this week — thanks to everyone who sent them in!)
issueTitle: A better way to take video on your phone

title: Orion
description: Kino. The team at Lux doesn’t really miss. They made Halide for photos, the nifty Orion iPad monitor tool, and now Kino, a video app that is somehow both really simple and absurdly powerful. I love a good noir filter. (I got a lot of recommendations for this one this week — thanks to everyone who sent them in!)
issueTitle: A better way to take video on your phone

title: The Fitbit Ace LTE
description: The Fitbit Ace LTE.
issueTitle: A better way to take video on your phone

title: Arc for Windows
description: Arc for Windows. Arc is still my favorite browser, and even in this first version, it’s surprisingly solid on Windows. (Though it is missing a couple of Arc’s more advanced features and some of the AI stuff.) If you try it, give it time — it’s a really big change from Chrome, but I’m still sold on it.
issueTitle: The best new browser for Windows

title: Cleft
issueTitle: An AI voice notes app that really works

title: The Nothing Phone 2A
description: The Nothing Phone 2A.
issueTitle: The perfect music streaming app does not exist

title: Bose’s Ultra Open Earbuds
description: Bose’s Ultra Open Earbuds. For some reason, over the last year or so, almost all in-ear headphones suddenly leave my ears sore and scratchy.
issueTitle: How to live your life in text files

title: open to everyone
description: Bluesky. The cool kids club of social media is now open to everyone! And as every site is required to do, it promptly crashed in a bunch of big and funny ways as people poured in.
issueTitle: The hottest new(ish) thing in social networks

title: fill out the survey
description: I also have for you a new webcam, a new word game, a new show about monsters, a new iMessage hack, and a whole bunch more. Oh, and a favor to ask: we’re doing a survey on how people use The Verge and what you might want from a “Verge subscription.” If you have thoughts and are up for helping us out, please take a second to fill out the survey. Thanks in advance!
issueTitle: The silly word game you didn’t know you needed

title: Internet Artifacts
description: Internet Artifacts. Neal Agarwal’s whole
issueTitle: Your guide to the internet’s most (and least) important moments

title: whole
description: Internet Artifacts. Neal Agarwal’s whole
issueTitle: Your guide to the internet’s most (and least) important moments

title: The Apple iPhone 16E
description: The Apple iPhone 16E. I’m torn on this one. I like that it’s $599, I like that it has good battery life, I like that it has Face ID and USB-C. But only one camera? And an Action Button but no MagSafe? Some odd tradeoffs here, and for a higher price than the old SE, but this’ll surely be the phone for a lot of iPhone users.
issueTitle: Our favorite apps for listening to music

title: it has Face ID and USB-C
description: The Apple iPhone 16E. I’m torn on this one. I like that it’s $599, I like that it has good battery life, I like that it has Face ID and USB-C. But only one camera? And an Action Button but no MagSafe? Some odd tradeoffs here, and for a higher price than the old SE, but this’ll surely be the phone for a lot of iPhone users.
issueTitle: Our favorite apps for listening to music

title: The Framework Laptop 12
description: The Framework Laptop 12. All my PC gamer friends are more excited about the Framework Desktop, but I think the company’s cheapest (and best-looking) laptop is going to be one to watch.
issueTitle: Our favorite speakers, headphones, and other music gear

title: Framework Desktop
description: The Framework Laptop 12. All my PC gamer friends are more excited about the Framework Desktop, but I think the company’s cheapest (and best-looking) laptop is going to be one to watch.
issueTitle: Our favorite speakers, headphones, and other music gear

title: The new MacBook Air
description: The new MacBook Air. The MacBook Air is probably my longest-running default recommendation. If you just want a laptop, no follow-up questions, get an Air. This one’s faster and has a better webcam, and I even like the pale blue here. And it’s cheaper! A miracle!
issueTitle: Some nice upgrades for Apple’s best gadgets

title: The new iPad
description: The new iPad. The new iPad Air got all of Apple’s attention this week, but I think the new base model is the bigger deal.
issueTitle: Some nice upgrades for Apple’s best gadgets

title: iPad Air
description: The new iPad. The new iPad Air got all of Apple’s attention this week, but I think the new base model is the bigger deal.
issueTitle: Some nice upgrades for Apple’s best gadgets

title: The Core 2 Duo
description: The Core 2 Duo. I have so many fond memories of Pebble smartwatches, which combined features, battery life, and simplicity better than basically anything I’ve used since. And now they’re back! They’re not called Pebbles, but they’re Pebbles.
issueTitle: An old smartwatch favorite makes a comeback

title: Plex
description: Plex. Plex has spent a lot of time and energy trying to become a proper, legit streaming platform, and the new mobile app is by far the most mainstream-useful thing it has ever made.
issueTitle: One streaming app to (almost) rule them all

title: Blue Prince
description: Blue Prince. Technically this came out last week, when we were off, but so many of you told me how much you love it that I feel obligated to include it here.
issueTitle: Everybody’s got a favorite new game

title: One Million Chessboards
description: One Million Chessboards. From the creator of One Million Checkboxes, one of the internet’s most bizarre and riveting social experiences, this is even more fun: a million chessboards, all playing at once.
issueTitle: A worthy sequel to one of the best websites ever

title: The Sony WH-1000XM6
description: The Sony WH-1000XM6. Sony’s over-ear headphones have been the best on the market for the last few years. The new ones aren’t exactly, you know, mind-blowing, and $450 is a lot, but I’ll take the improvements across the board — especially the better mics and noise cancelling.
issueTitle: The best wireless headphones get even better

title: Doom:
issueTitle: The best wireless headphones get even better

title: kind of can’t believe it
description: Fortnite for iOS. It’s back! I kind of can’t believe it! I fell off the Fortnite wagon pretty hard over the last year or so, but this and my Backbone Pro are going to be very good friends going forward.
issueTitle: Summer blockbuster season is here

title: !Camera
issueTitle: The most fun camera app I’ve used in forever

title: Dia
issueTitle: Would you switch browsers for a chatbot?

title: heat dome
description: Hi, friends! Welcome to Installer No. 88, your guide to the best and Verge-iest stuff in the world. (If you’re new here, welcome, happy heat dome, and also you can read all the old editions at the Installer homepage.)
issueTitle: Apple’s racing movie is finally here

title: Raycast
description: And in the interest of filling up the Gmail for Jay, I have a question: what’s your favorite non-famous app? A few of you have recently reached out to remind me that yes, everyone knows Instagram and WhatsApp, but all of us power users take so much software for granted and forget that not everybody knows about them. So let’s share the stuff we know all too well! My current favorites are probably Raycast,
issueTitle: Apple’s racing movie is finally here

title: on Twitch
description: The show, which you can watch for free on Twitch, typically ends very early in the morning on Sunday, and you can watch replays on the Games Done Quick YouTube channel. My two favorite runs so far have been a Beat
issueTitle: Foldables are in and suddenly really thin

title: OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent
description: OpenAI’s ChatGPT Agent: OpenAI’s new agent can now “do work for you using its own computer,” like briefing you about your calendar or finding flights on Expedia.
issueTitle: The Switch 2’s next killer app is already here

title: Apple’s public betas
description: Apple’s public betas: Public betas for iOS 26, iPadOS 26, macOS Tahoe 26, watchOS 26, and tvOS 26 are available now, giving you a chance to see Apple’s Liquid Glass design language in action before the updates are released widely this fall. I’ve been running the developer betas, and after some necessary tweaks from Apple, I’m warming up to Liquid Glass more than I expected.
issueTitle: Apple beta season is here

title: Maingear’s
issueTitle: Apple beta season is here

title: Elgato Facecam 4K
description: Elgato Facecam 4K: This $199.99 webcam can record in 4K resolution and 60fps and lets you swap in 49mm lens filters and dial in your ISO, white balance, and shutter speed. It’s still a webcam, but that flexibility might make it feel a little more like a real camera.
issueTitle: A webcam that’s almost like a real camera

title: LG StanbyMe 2
description: LG StanbyMe 2: I have legitimately considered buying a TV on wheels for my home (I think storing the TV when I’m not watching it would be very useful!), so LG’s second-generation portable display, which you can now buy, is kind of appealing to me.
issueTitle: A webcam that’s almost like a real camera

title: OpenAI’s GPT-5
description: OpenAI’s GPT-5: OpenAI’s next major AI model is finally out. The company promises it has “state-of-the-art performance” across many different types of work and is “significantly less likely to hallucinate” than its previous models. You can try it out right now in ChatGPT, even if you’re on the free plan.
issueTitle: The next big AI model is here

title: OpenAI’s GPT-OSS
description: OpenAI’s GPT-OSS: Ahead of GPT-5, OpenAI also made a splash with the release of GPT-OSS, its two new open-weight models that you can run on a laptop.
issueTitle: The next big AI model is here

title: run on a laptop
description: OpenAI’s GPT-OSS: Ahead of GPT-5, OpenAI also made a splash with the release of GPT-OSS, its two new open-weight models that you can run on a laptop.
issueTitle: The next big AI model is here

title: Teenage Engineering’s Computer-2 PC case
description: Teenage Engineering’s Computer-2 PC case: This small form factor PC case has some awesome Teenage Engineering flair. I love the hazy, semi-transparent look. Even better, the company is also giving it away for free — that is, when it’s back in stock again. At least you can sign up for a waitlist.
issueTitle: Teenage Engineering did it again

title: Fairphone’s new cables and chargers
description: Fairphone’s new cables and chargers: Fairphone says its new accessories are more durable than what it offered before and made with sustainability in mind.
issueTitle: Teenage Engineering did it again

title: Pixel 10 Pro Fold
description: Pixel 10 Pro Fold. Google’s newest foldable has an IP68 ingress rating, meaning that it should be significantly more resistant to dust than other foldables. The company made it happen with a new gearless hinge design. When you’re paying nearly $2,000 for your phone, having some extra confidence in its durability goes a long way.
issueTitle: The most fun way to look through old photos

title: Pixel Watch 4
description: Pixel Watch 4. The newest Pixel Watch has screws on its chassis that you can remove to more easily repair and replace the screen and the battery.
issueTitle: The most fun way to look through old photos

title: Hue Essentials
description: Hue Essentials. Philips Hue has a new lineup of cheaper smart lightbulbs starting at $25 per bulb (or $15 each as part of a four-pack), making them much cheaper than its flagship color-changing bulbs.
issueTitle: A really cheap way to get really smart lights
